title: Data domain segmentation example 3
content:
This example uses the Request record type to demonstrate data domain segmentation for two companies (Company A and Company B) that you manage within one tenant.

  1. Log in to the tenant as the tenant admin.
  2. From the main menu, go to Administration > Configuration > Lists. Edit the Data domains list to add the following two domains: Company_A and Company_B.
  3. Go to Administration > Configuration > Studio, do the following:
    • Open the Person record, and then add the Primary domain and Data domains fields to the Person forms (New and Full).
    • Open the Request record, and then add the Data domains field to the withoutResolution form.
  4. Go to Administration > Master data > People, click ROLES, and then create a new role named SP_agent with the following permissions:
    • General > Log into the application
    • Security >View all data domains permission
    • Record types > Request > View and Update
  5. Log in to Suite Administration as suite-admin (https://<External Access Host>/bo), open the tenant record, and turn on the Manage users in tenant option. This option enables the tenant admin to create users directly from the agent interface.
  6. Go to Administration > Master data > People, and then click New to create five users of the DB authentication type with the following settings:
    • Sally (ESS user of Company A): Data domains=Company_A, Primary domain=Company_A, Roles=Self-Service Portal User
    • Danny (ESS user of Company B): Data domains=Company_B, Primary domain=Company_B, Roles=Self-Service Portal User
    • Tony (SP agent): Data domains=Public, Primary domain=(empty value), Roles=Self-Service Portal User and SP_agent
    • Jeffery (Company A agent): Data domains=Company_A, Primary domain=Company_A, Role=Self-Service Portal User, and Request Approver
    • Joanna (Company B agent): Data domains=Company_B, Primary domain=Company_B, Role=Self-Service Portal User and Request Approver
    Make sure that a mail server is already configured in Bo > Configurations > Email Service, then open each user record and click Reset password to activate the user accounts.
  7. Go to Administration > Master data > Groups, and then create a group named Group_A, set its Primary domain to Company_A, and then click Add in the Group members section to add user Sally to this group.
  8. Similarly, create another group named Group_B, set its Primary domain to Company_B, and then add Danny to this group.
  9. Go to Plan > Service Catalog > Offerings, open an offering (for example, the out-of-the-box offering named Request PC Phone Service), and then click Default values and select Group_A in the Service Desk group field, and go to the Audience section on the General tab to add Group_A. This offering is referred to as offering A in a later step, and will be available for Sally and not for Danny.
  10. Similarly, update another offering for Group_B. This offering is referred to as offering B in a later step, and will be available for Danny and not for Sally.
  11. Log in to Service Portal as Sally and then submit a request for offering A.
  12. Log in to Service Portal as Danny, and then submit a request for offering B.
  13. Log in to the agent interface as Jeffery, and check that you can see only the request that Sally submitted. Additionally, the Data domains field of the request is populated with a value of Company_A, which is the Primary domain of Group_A.
  14. Log in to the agent interface as Joanna, and check that you can see only the request that Danny submitted. Additionally, the Data domains field of the request is populated with a value of Company_B, which is Primary domain of Group_B.
  15. Log in to the agent interface as Tony, and check that you can see both of the requests that Sally and Danny submitted.
